newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares weaker in early bourse dealings.
newsitem.headline: German shares weaker in early bourse dealings.

text.p: German shares were generally lower in early bourse dealings as Daimler-Benz AG took a beating after two major investment banks lowered earnings estimates on the industrial group.
The 30-share DAX index was down 28.72 points at 4,410.21 points, while the IBIS DAX, which reflects all-day computer dealings, was up 5.06 points at 4,410.58 points.
Dealers expected the market to remain under pressure throughout the session from profit-taking and ahead of the release at 1230 GMT of U.S. July unemployment data.

Market attention focused on Merill Lynch and Morgan Stanley downgrading 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates for Daimler. Merrill also cut Daimler to intermediate reduce from neutral but left the share as a long-term hold.
The downgrades came after Daimler released six-month results that showed group operating profit more than doubling to 1.849 billion marks.
Daimler shares were down six marks at 148.80 marks and were among the top percentage losers during the bourse session.
Daimler chief executive Juergen Schrempp said in a radio interview on Friday that he did not understand the disappointment among analysts.
"It is a excellent performance when a company more than doubles its operating profit," Schrempp told InfoRadio.
Some traders said the drop was an overreaction and ABN AMRO issued a buy recommendation on Daimler.
Other major DAX index components were lower, including banking industry shares such as Commerzbank AG and Deutsche Bank AG.
Commerzbank was down 45 pfennigs at 62.55 marks, while Deutsche was down 2.50 marks at 122 marks.
